pull.title: docs: Less confusing documentation for `torpassword`
pull.body:
The current documentation leads the reader to think `hash-password` is an other option. 
This change is less confusing and make it clear how to use this option.

verification.payload:
tree 8518458c9a6657d2bd098960b22623f0fa50c639
parent 29f429dc7d4c7e6cd012e749cadf89e3138bcab3

Less confusing documentation for `torpassword`

The current documentation leads the reader to think `hash-password` is an other option. 
This change is less confusing and make it clear how to use this option.

events.message:
Less confusing documentation for `torpassword`

The current documentation leads the reader to think `hash-password` is an other option. 
This change is less confusing and make it clear how to use this option.

events.body:
As a note, `--hash-password` comes from here: https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-manual.html.en#opt-hash-password

Concept ACK
@sp4ke could you please [squash your commits](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits), then this can be merged.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,8 +110,8 @@ are seen with `-debug=tor` they can be resolved by adding both the user running
 the user running bitcoind to the same group and setting permissions appropriately. On
 Debian-based systems the user running bitcoind can be added to the debian-tor group,
 which has the appropriate permissions. An alternative authentication method is the use
-of the `-torpassword` flag and a `hash-password` which can be enabled and specified in
-Tor configuration.
+of the `-torpassword=hashpassword` option. The `hashpassword` can be enabled and specified in
+Tor configuration under the `HashedControlPassword` option.
comments.body:
it's an improvement but still not fully clear as to what actually needs to be done to set up tor password authentication. to be clear:
- bitcoind's `torpassword` takes the *unhashed* password
- tor's configuration `HashedControlPassword` has a hashed password
IIRC they have a command that can either hash a password for their configuration file, or generate a password and show both the actual and hashed password

the way that this is worded, it sounds like bitcoind's argument takes the hashes password too

comments.body: I just pushed an other change that adds more details on the relation between `password` and `HashedControlPassword`.
